Ligon, a native of Appomattox County, general manager of the Bryant division of the Westinghouse Electric corporation, who will retire December 31, 1972, was honored on November 12th, at a reception in the Holiday Inn, Bridgeport, Connecticut. The December, 1972, issue Westinghouse New, Bryant division, was entirely dedicat ed to him and was headed The Ligon Years - A Lasting Legacy. Along side a large picture of Mr. Ligon on the front page of the company newspaper, was the following What A Way To Go - Flags flying, Bands playing and Bryant surpassing all expect- ions! Yes, the Ligon years have been a lasting legacy. A legacy of unparalleled growth and accomplishment. A period of years marked by continued employment and new product development. To Willard Du- puy Ligon, as a testimonial to your 43 year Westinghouse career and its spectacular conclusion at Bryant Electric, we dedicate this issue of the Westinghouse News. Ligon was appointed General Manager of the Bryant Divi sion of the Westinghouse Corporation in 1963, having joined the company in 1929, after graduating from Virginia Polytechnic Institute with a B.S. in industrial engineering. A native of Pamplin, Virginia, he graduated from Blackstone Military Institute prior to attending V.P.I., Blacksburg, Virginia. He is married to the former Mary Brightwell of Pamplin. His first Westinghouse as signment was as a foreman in the Motor Division at East Pittsburg, Pa. He rose to general foreman, assistant superintendent and superin tendent. While in this division, at the end of World War II, Mr. Ligon was moved to Buffalo, New York, along with the division, and served as resident manager and then was appointed manager of the Motor Division. He was named general works manager of the combined Motor and Control Divisions at Buffalo in 1950.
